Dear Ms. Williams:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (248) 975-5053.

ALLEGATION:
On 10/16/2022 Youth A propped open his bedroom door and Youth B stuffed her
bed and went into Youth A’s bedroom. Staff Person 1 found Youth A and Youth B
engaging in sexual intercourse on her third bedroom monitoring check. Incident
occurred on Vemco unit.
INVESTIGATION:
Complainant
I spoke with Complainant on 10/18/2022. Complainant did not have additional
information regarding this allegation.
Youth A
I interviewed Youth A on 10/18/2022 at Mott Children’s Residence with another
Department of Health and Human Service worker. Youth A stated he had sexual
intercourse with Youth B on 10/15/2022 and 10/16/2022 in his bedroom. Youth A
stated he used a shoe to keep his bedroom door open on 10/15/2022 at bedtime.
(Youth A and Youth B’s bedroom are next to each other.) Youth A stated Youth B
came into his bedroom and left without staff knowing. Youth A stated he used a shoe
again on 10/16/2022 to keep his bedroom door open and Youth B went in to his
bedroom at bedtime. Youth A stated he pretended to be asleep when a staff person
entered his bedroom and found Youth B hidden under a blanket in the corner of his
bedroom. Youth A stated he was moved to another unit on 10/16/2022. Youth A
stated he was seen at a hospital on 10/17/2022. Youth A stated he has not
participated in other sexual activity at Mott Children’s Residence. Youth A stated
Youth C told staff about his sexual activity with Youth B because he refused to have
sexual relations with Youth C.
Youth A was asked how staff complete bedtime room checks. Youth A stated staff
unlock the bedroom door and check on the youth.
Youth B
I interviewed Youth B at Mott Children’s Residence on 10/18/2022 with another
Department of Health and Human Service worker. Youth B stated she gave Youth C
a note on 10/15/2022 to pass to Youth A. The note was a plan for Youth B to go into
Youth A’s bedroom. Youth B stated she returned from an outing and Youth A said,
“Yeah” in response to her note. Youth B stated she placed a stuffed animal with
towels and blankets under a blanket on her bed and placed a bonnet on the stuff
animal’s head to make it look like she was in bed facing the wall because she knew
staff performed bedtime room checks. Youth B stated Youth A left his bedroom door
cracked open and she went to Youth A’s bedroom for an hour to an hour and a half
and had sexual intercourse with him. Youth B stated a female staff person shined a
light into Youth A’s bedroom, but Youth B was hidden under a blanket lying between
Youth A and a wall and was not seen. Youth B stated there were additional bedtime
room checks before she returned to her bedroom. Youth B was asked how she
returned to her bedroom without staff being aware. Youth B stated she had Youth A
open and close his bedroom door to sound the alarm and Youth B walked up the
3

hallway and asked staff for permission to use the bathroom. Youth B stated she then
asked staff to unlock her bedroom door to go back to bed. Youth B stated Youth A
asked her repeatedly if she was mad at him throughout the day and at dinner on
10/16/2022 and asked if she was coming to this bedroom. Youth B stated she
agreed when Youth A said he wanted her to come to his bedroom. Youth B stated
she stuffed her bed like she did on 10/15/2022 and Youth A left his bedroom door
ajar again. Youth B stated she went into Youth A’s bedroom and they talked and had
sexual intercourse. Youth B stated Staff Person 1 knocked on her bedroom door,
called her name and then unlocked Youth A’s bedroom door, entered Youth A’s
bedroom, turned on the lights and pulled the blanket off Youth B. Youth B stated
Youth C informed Staff Person 1 that she was in Youth A’s bedroom. Youth B stated
she was seen at a hospital on 10/17/2022.
Youth C
I interviewed Youth C at Mott Children’s Residence on 10/18/2022 with another
Department of Health and Human Service worker. Youth C stated Youth B gave her
a note on 10/15/2022 to pass to Youth A. Youth C stated the note said, “Leave your
door open tonight and we’re gonna talk.” Youth C stated Youth B told her at
breakfast on 10/16/2022 that she and Youth A did the “devil’s tango” (sexual
intercourse) and they were going to do it again. Youth C stated she knew Youth B
was in Youth A’s bedroom on 10/16/2022 at bedtime and told Staff Person 1 that
Youth B created a ‘dummy’ of herself in her bed. Youth C stated Staff Person 1
found Youth B in Youth A’s bedroom.
Staff Person 1
I interviewed Staff Person 1 at Mott Children’s Residence on 10/18/2022 with
another Department of Health and Human Service worker. Staff Person 1 stated
bedtime on 10/16/2022 was busy due to youths coming out of their bedrooms. Staff
Person 1 stated Youth C told her that Youth B was in Youth A’s bedroom after Staff
Person 2 left the unit. Staff Person 1 stated she went to Youth B’s bedroom and saw
a figure in the bed and went to Youth A’s bedroom and saw Youth A’s face in his
bed. Staff Person 1 stated Youth C then told Staff Person 1 that Youth B made it
seem like she was sleeping in bed, but she was in Youth A’s bedroom. Staff Person
1 stated she looked for headphones, but ended up taking a poster to Youth B’s
bedroom to use as a reason to knock on Youth B’s bedroom door. Staff Person 1
stated she knocked on Youth B’s bedroom door and there was no reply. Staff
Person 1 stated she then opened Youth B’s bedroom door and called Youth B’s
name with no reply. Staff Person 1 stated she entered Youth B’s bedroom and
touched the figure in the bed and found a stuffed animal. Staff Person 1 stated she
called management for assistance. Staff Person 1 stated Supervisor 1 came to
Vemco unit and went into Youth A’s bedroom and pulled the blanket up in the corner
of the bedroom and found Youth B. Staff Person 1 stated Youth B told Supervisor 1
that she was talking to Youth A. Staff Person 1 stated Supervisor 1 returned Youth B
to her bedroom.
4

Staff Person 1 was asked to explain bedtime room checks. Staff Person 1 stated
bedroom checks are staggered and done every 13 to 16 minutes. Staff Person 1
stated each bedroom is checked for the youth and documented. Staff Person 1
stated she is not sure if she saw Youth A’s face or a body part (hand, arm, foot, leg,
etc.) when she completed bedroom checks on 10/16/2022 prior to Youth C telling
her that Youth B was in Youth A’s bedroom.
Staff Person 2
I interviewed Staff Person 2 on 11/04/2022 by telephone. Staff Person 2 stated she
is assigned to Johnson unit, but worked with Staff Person 1 on Vemco unit on
10/16/2022 until 8:31 pm when Staff Person 2 clocked out. Staff Person 2 stated
many youths struggle with the transition to bedtime despite having a set routine.
Staff Person 2 stated room monitoring forms begin approximately at 8:00 pm once
the youths are in their bedrooms for the evening. Staff Person 2 stated Staff Person
1 completed bedroom checks on 10/16/2022. Staff Person 2 stated she was not
aware Youth B went into Youth A’s bedroom on 10/16/2022.
Supervisor 1
I interviewed Supervisor 1 on 11/04/2022 by telephone. Supervisor 1 stated she was
on Vemco unit in a youth’s doorway reading a bedtime story on 10/16/2022 until she
was called to assist on another unit. Supervisor 1 stated she then received a call
about a youth alleging Youth B was in Youth A’s bedroom on Vemco unit.
Supervisor 1 stated she returned to Vemco unit and walked with Staff Person 1 to
Youth A’s bedroom. Supervisor 1 stated she found Youth B under a blanket in the
corner of Youth A’s bedroom. Supervisor 1 stated Youth B returned to her bedroom
and there was a stuffed animal wearing a shower cap under the covers in Youth B’s
bed. Supervisor 1 stated she called management and moved Youth A off the unit.
Video footage
10/15/2022, Saturday, video footage was not available due to a system issue.
Continuous video footage was unavailable after the system issue was resolved.
On 10/18/2022, video footage from 10/16/2022 was viewed. The video footage
shows Vemco unit bedroom hallway. It shows Youth B walks down the bedroom
hallway at 8:23 pm. It shows Staff Person 1 and Staff Person 2 sitting on the couch
facing almost 90 degrees to the right of the bedroom hallway. It shows Youth B
enters a bedroom. It shows Youth A walks up the bedroom hallway and speaks with
Staff Person 2 and places a beverage in the refrigerator and heads back down the
bedroom hallway to a bedroom. It shows a youth in his doorway and another youth
in the bedroom hallway. It shows Staff Person 1 checks on a youth and Staff Person
2 leaves Vemco unit at 8:28 pm. It shows Staff Person 1 talks to a youth in the
bedroom hallway and then picks up clothes from the bedroom hallway floor. It shows
no youth in the bedroom hallway. It shows Staff Person 1 sitting on the couch. It
shows Supervisor 1 comes out of a bedroom and walks to the end of the hallway
and then walks up to speak with Staff Person 1 before leaving the unit. It shows
Youth C walks up the bedroom hallway at 8:36 pm and sits on the couch with Staff
5

Person 1 and at 8:39 pm both get up. It shows Staff Person 1 walks to the end of the
bedroom hallway and returns to Youth A and Youth B’s bedroom area and then
walks up the bedroom hallway and speaks with Youth C. It shows Staff Person 1
and Youth C walk down the bedroom hallway and Youth C enters a bedroom and
Staff Person 1 takes a large paper and walks to Youth A and Youth B’s bedroom
area and then uses her cell phone. It shows Youth C is out of her bedroom. It shows
Supervisor 1 walks down the bedroom hallway with Staff Person 1 at 8:53 pm. It
shows Youth B exits a bedroom and talks with Staff Person 1 and Supervisor 1.
Video footage does not capture Supervisor 1 in a youth’s bedroom doorway reading.
Video footage does not show a staff person checking on each youth in their
bedroom from 08:15 pm to 09:45 pm.

Bedtime policy and procedure
Mott Children’s Residence bedtime policy and procedure states “Staff are reminded:
To perform bed checks every 15 minutes at random intervals. When performing the
bed check the staff must visually see that the child is in their bed.” Program manger
states visual check constitutes seeing a youth’s face or body (hand, arm, foot, leg,
etc.)
6

Incident report
Staff Person 1 and Supervisor 1 wrote incident reports dated 10/16/2022 regarding
Youth B being in Youth A’s bedroom. The incident reports coincide with their
interview statements.
Personnel file
Staff Person 1 was hired on 08/01/2022. Staff Person 1 does not have a discipline
history. Staff Person 1 completed room monitoring training during new hire
orientation in 08/2022.
Another Department of Health and Human Service agency completed an
investigation with finding.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision methods for addressing residents’
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
7

ANALYSIS: Youth B entered Youth A’s bedroom on 10/16/2022 during
bedtime hours. Mott Children’s Residence policy and procedure
states “staff must visually see that the child is in their bed”
during bedtime room checks. A visual check is interpreted as
seeing a youth’s face, or body (hand, arm, foot, leg etc.) to
confirm that the youth is in their bedroom. Staff Person 1 did not
recall if she visually confirmed Youth B was in her bedroom on
10/16/2022.
Youth A and Youth B stated Youth B also entered Youth A’s
bedroom on 10/15/2022 without staff awareness. Video footage
for 10/15/2022 bedtime is not available and there are no incident
reports of Youth B being in Youth A’s bedroom on 10/15/2022.
CONSULTATION:
Staff walk each youth to their bedroom and physically and
securely close the youth’s bedroom door at bedtime. Another
option is to have a group of youth stand by their bedroom doors
and enter their bedroom at the same time and staff then
physically check that each bedroom door is securely closed.
Staff walk to a youth’s bedroom when called or knocking on the
door is heard and observe the youth exiting their bedroom.
Staff walk a youth back to their bedroom if youth was given
permission to exit and physically and securely close the youth’s
bedroom door.
Staff position themselves to face the bedroom hallway during
bedtime hours.
Staff check youth bedroom doors to ensure alarms are in
working condition and place maintenance orders if needed.
Staff should not be in a youth’s bedroom with a youth if another
staff person is not directly present.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
REPEAT VIOLATION 2022C0325036
Corrective action plan pending
8

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4127 Staff-to-resident ratio.
(4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
checks of residents. The time between the variable interval
checks shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
ANALYSIS: 10/16/2022 video tape review and bedtime room monitoring
form does not reflect a staff person went to each bedroom to
check on the status of the youth from 08:15 pm to 09:45 pm due
to Youth A and Youth B’s sexual acting out. All youths must be
monitored while asleep or outside of direct staff supervision in
intervals not exceeding fifteen minutes.
10/15/2022 and 10/16/2022 bedtime room monitoring forms
were reviewed. Documented bedtime room checks exceeded
fifteen-minute variable intervals on multiple occasions on both
dates.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
qualifications.
(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the
following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
(b) Experience to perform the duties of the position assigned.
ANALYSIS: Another Department of Health and Human Service agency
completed an investigation with finding on Staff person 1.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9

The continuance of a regular license is recommended for Mott Children’s Residence

sir_summary.summary: On October 16, 2022, at the Mott Children's Residence, two youth engaged in sexual intercourse after one propped open his door and the other stuffed her bed to appear present, with staff discovering them only after a tip from another youth. The investigation substantiated multiple violations, including failure to conduct required visual bed checks every 15 minutes, failure to follow bedtime supervision policies, and concerns about a staff member's qualifications. Culpability lies with the facility for systemic supervision failures, as evidenced by repeated lapses in monitoring and a prior similar violation.

sir_violation_level.justification: The report substantiates sexual intercourse (sexual abuse) between Youth A and Youth B occurring on two dates (10/15/2022 and 10/16/2022) during bedtime, along with failure of staff to detect the youth entering another's bedroom due to inadequate visual checks and monitoring intervals exceeding 15 minutes. Sexual intercourse falls under the 'Safety and Violence' category for severe SIRs.
